description.narrative: The Accelerator Labs are UNDP’s new way of working in development. Together with core partners, the State of Qatar and the Federal Republic of Germany, 60 labs serving 78 countries will work together

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Network have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative: 1.1 0 number data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 0 different data sources used 1.3 0 sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 0 innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. 2.1 0 Learning shared from the accelerator lab with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 0 lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners. 2.3 0 partners and governments increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite. 2.4 0 UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 3.1 0 network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 No new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 No engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 No influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Network have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem. • No staff hired for the accelerator lab • No office set up

1.1 2 new sources of data. 1.2 3 different data sources. 1.3 20 new potential solutions 1.4 2 innovations methods per portfolio 2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 5 % of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem
Other targets related to setting up the team at CO
• Deploy 3 NoB staff for the accelerator lab • Equip staff with required office material and equipment • Design and setting up the Accelerator Lab office

1.1 2 new sources of data (Open data, crowd sourcing). 1.2 2 different data sources (Open data, crowd sourcing) 1.3 4 solutions co-created ( https://www.et.undp.org/content/ethiopia/en/home/blog/co-creating-solutions-with-youth.html ) 1.4 2 Innovation methods per portfolio (portfolio sense making and issue mapping) 2.1 2 blogs published (Please see the blogs on Ethiopia CO page) 2.2 100 % of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart 2.3 Two government entities or partners have learned about Accelerator lab methods (Ministry of Innovation and Technology and Entrepreneurship Development Center - EDC) 2.4 100% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 The lab interacted at least once a week with another lab in the network. 10 interaction per year. 3.2 50 % of information shared across the network are methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured three times in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. (2 blogs published on our website, innovation week event and Acc. launch event shared on our social media) 3.4 Connected the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. (UN Ethiopia and Embassy of Israel featured the news of the lab launch)
Other CO related results
• Internal and national level lab launch • 3 NoB staffs have been deployed, and one additional service contract holder staff deployed to assist the core lab team with CO’s extra commitment. • All the lab staff members have been equipped with necessary material and office equipment • Design of the accelerator lab office has been finalized and the actual work has been out sourced to a contractor to set up the office as per the design.

1.1 5 new sources of data. 1.2 6 different data sources. 1.3 35 new potential solutions 1.4 5 innovations methods per portfolio 2.1 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 5 % of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
Other CO specific targets
• Sign an MOU with at least 1 partner • Organize 1 policy brief on innovation • 4 experience exchange visits

1.1 5 new sources of data (raw data, social media, survey, mobile data, citizen data ) 1.2 7 different data sources used. (raw data, social media, survey, mobile data, open data, citizen data, satellite imagery/Google earth) 1.3 25 solutions mapped (see solutions on the Global Acc lab solutions data base) 1.4 7 Innovation methods per portfolio (collective intelligence, cocreation, solution mapping, experimentation, foresight, Human centered design, horizon scanning) 2.1 10 blogs published (Please see the blogs on Global Acc lab web page) 2.2 100 % of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 5 government entities or partners have learned about Accelerator lab methods (Ethiopia Technology and Innovation Institute, Job Creation Commission, INSA, Federal Civil Service Commission, Industrial Parks Development Commission and the lab team introduced the lab to other 30+ potential partners including government, the privates sector, associations, UN agencies and NGOs. 2.4 100% of our learning challenges provided actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 The lab interacted at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 50 % of information shared across the network are methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured 17 times in the year in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. (Our 10 blogs and 5 webinars and Challenge competitions featured on CO webpage and social media channels) 3.4 Connected the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 7 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem
Other results
• MoU signed with with Ministry of innovation and Technology • 3 local experience exchange visits conducted.

1.1 10 new sources of data 1.2 9 different data sources. 1.3 50 new potential solutions 1.4 10 innovations methods per portfolio 2.1 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 50 % of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem

1.1 9 new sources of data used (Open data, Ethnography data, Geospatial data, Big & Raw data (Structured, unstructured, semi-structured data), Focus group discussion, Direct Interview, Survey, Mobile data, satellite image) 1.2 8 different data sources used (Open data, Ethnography data, Geospatial data, Big & Raw data (Structured, unstructured, semi-structured data), Focus group discussion, Direct Interview, Survey, Mobile data) 1.3 47 new potential solutions (Refer Acc Lab solutions mapping platform) 1.4 13 innovations methods per portfolio (Sense making, Behavioral Insight, Backstabbing and Desired future, Scenario planning, Horizon scanning, Collective intelligence, Prototyping, Co-creation, Human-Centered Design, Design Thinking, Solutions Mapping, Ethnography) 2.1 9 blogs, or 3 other (substantial) media posts published per year. (refer the blog tracker) 2.2 75% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart (refer to learning cycle closing report for details on partners engaged) 2.3 2 government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods (Ethiopia Biotechnology Institute - EBTi and Bahirdar University) 2.4 100% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. (List of CO projects benefited from lab learnings; NAMA Compost, UNDP- SIDA Environment and Climate Change, BCP, Inclusive and Innovative Finance, COVID -19 recovery, Beautifying Sheger, Innovation for Development, Ethiopia National Youth Volunteer Community Service) 3.1 The lab interacted once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 100 % of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. (refer to our blogs, publications and updates) 3.3 The Accelerator Labs work is featured once per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. (@UNDPEthiopia) 3.4 Connected the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identified and engaged with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem
